Award.AwardTitle: Optimizing Student Learning Outcomes: A Comparative Study of Onsite, Virtual, and Remote Laboratories in Electrical Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Participating Institutions: University of North Texas (lead), Texas Woman's University and University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez

Project Description
This project is studying onsite, virtual, and remote laboratories used in undergraduate engineering education, garnering measureable learning outcomes (e.g., ABET) to examine the interaction effects of lab designs, instructional input, and student demographics. The goal is to establish a framework for developing a blended learning environment in which different laboratory designs (onsite, virtual, and remote) function in concert to enhance student learning and attitudes and improve educational practice.

Information technologies have created far-reaching transitional effects on how instruction is delivered and students learn. This project is advancing an understanding of the impact of this transition on student learning outcomes and the engineering curriculum as a whole. The end products will include: (1) New labs - remote and virtual labs are being designed, implemented and evaluated through four project courses. The Virtual Instructor module within these designs is providing students a more realistic learning environment. (2) Student-centered pedagogical design - by using a project-oriented lab curriculum, students are exploring their own path to learning by discovery of their solutions to lab problems. This modality enables the students to take control over the exploration and practice problem-solving skills, and fosters creativity. (3) Enhanced understanding of differing lab designs - a comparative study is examining the differences of effectiveness in support of student learning among different lab designs which, in turn, will help educators and researchers make more informed decisions regarding future lab development.

Broader Significance
The project is creating and offering laboratory instruction that appeals to students with diverse learning styles, backgrounds, and interests. The project hopes to improve the recruitment and retention of women and minority students in engineering by engaging them in the co-design of the learning experience, through a joint program with Texas Woman's University and cooperation with the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez. The project, through its dissemination activities, is expected to reach a broad audience of those interested in adopting the new labs by offering a choice of delivery types (onsite, virtual, and remote) to adapt for a specific implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project aimed of a comparative study of onsite, virtual, and remote laboratories used in undergraduate engineering education. Laboratory experiments are critical for engineering education. The explosive progress in computer and internet technologies has not only made virtual and remote access to lab experiment possible but has also reshaped the learning styles of many college students. While extensive research has been conducted to integrate new technologies into laboratory education in recent decades, very few studies provide systematic evaluation on the impact of student learning involving different laboratory designs, such as onsite, virtual, and remote laboratories. In this project, the PIs conducted qualitative and quantitative evaluation and assessment for various laboratories through the design- and project- oriented electrical engineering curriculum in the Department of Electrical Engineering at the University of North Texas (UNT).

Through this project, we have developed a systematic platform for comparative study, which includes the lab design, pre-test design, data collection, formative evaluation, data analysis, and summative evaluation. The procedures and instruments from this pilot study will be used for more extensive studies with more participants from other disciplinary and institutes. Even with small sampling pool, we also drew some conclusions on the connection between the learning styles and the learning outcomes. Our research suggests that a strong preference for receiving information in a Read/Write mode positively influence student performance in labs. Consequently, instructors should consider spending more time teaching students how to construct and coordinate reading materials in labs, rather than assuming that students enter the course with reading skills already in place. We will continue working on the project with collaboration with other departments for long-term data collection and analysis.

The project has involved two minority universities: Texas Woman’s University and University of Puerto Rico and Mayaguez. The comparative study has been extended to students from these two universities with the goal of better understanding of diverse learning styles, background, and interests. In the summers of 2012 and 2013, we also participated the research experiences for teachers project to engage twelve local high school STEM teachers in electrical engineering research. The goals for these activities are to provide teachers an enhanced knowledge base in electrical engineering and increase the teacher’s ability to motivate students in STEM disciplines.


Last Modified: 12/26/2015
Modified by: Shengli Fu
